title: Explained : VAR history made at Women World Cup what referee did and why

The opening match of the 2023 Womenâ€™s World Cup featured a milestone moment as the referee explained a decision to supporters in the stadium.
Referee Yoshimi Yamashita (pictured) awarded a penalty to co-hosts New Zealand in the 88th minute after a VAR review, communicating the process via the Tannoy system at Eden Park in Auckland.

How is VAR working at the Womenâ€™s World Cup?
VAR is being used at the Womenâ€™s World Cup for the second successive tournament after its introduction in 2019.
Goals scored, mistaken identity, potential red cards and potential fouls in the penalty area will all be checked.
But FIFA announced at the start of July that referees would announce decisions over the loud speaker at games this summer.
This process happened previously at the menâ€™s FIFA Club World Cup in Morocco and the Under-20 World Cup in Argentina, but this is the first time live, in-play decisions have been heard at a senior World Cup tournament for men or women.
It was in January that footballâ€™s lawmakers, IFAB, agreed to trial broadcasting explanations of VAR decisions to the crowd and television audience at FIFA tournaments over the next 12 months.
The announcement, given in English after the decision has been made, can include all or some of the following elements: the final decision itself, the reason it has been given, which player committed the offence and, occasionally, some extra detail about the offence.
Kari Seitz, FIFAâ€™s head of refereeing in womenâ€™s football, said before the tournament: â€œThe most important thing for us is the decision on the field. If we can get all of that inside the announcement, great. But our priority is to make the correct decision. If we can explain these four things, thatâ€™s the extra content.

â€œIâ€™m confident we can get 80-90 per cent of this. Our goal is to make sure the spectators in the stands have a better understanding of whatâ€™s happening on the field.â€
FIFAâ€™s refereeing chief, Pierluigi Collina, said the development was about giving â€œmore transparency, more understanding of the decision made by the referee,â€ but admitted mistakes were possible given officials were still learning.
Collina said there were no plans to expand the information or decision-making process given live beyond the broadcast of the decision itself, adding that he did not want to put â€œpressureâ€ on referees speaking in a second language and further noting, when asked about other sports, that NFL officials had been â€œdoing this for quite a long timeâ€.
What happened in the tournament opener?
New Zealand, co-hosting the tournament with Australia, were leading 1-0 in the closing stages of the game when a late flashpoint ensued.
Jitka Klimkovaâ€™s team were attacking down the right flank when a Malia Steinmetz cross appeared to hit Tuva Hansenâ€™s hand with two minutes of normal time remaining.
On the advice of the VAR, Tatiana Guzman from Nicaragua, the referee headed to the pitchside monitor, with viewers and spectators able to see footage of the incident from several angles.
Satisfied that Hansenâ€™s outstretched arm had made her body illegally bigger, referee Yamashita pointed towards the spot and, for the first time in World Cup history, said: â€œThe decision isâ€¦ penaltyâ€.
Percival, New Zealandâ€™s most-capped player, failed to convert from the spot after her effort hit the crossbar, but the co-hosts hung on for a priceless victory.

Any chance this might happen in the Premier League?
Weâ€™ll have to wait and see.
Asked what the future might hold for VAR audio, Collina said: â€œAfter, we will discuss and consider what is best for the future.â€
The chief executive of the Football Association, who chaired the IFAB meeting in January, admitted he felt crowds did not currently receive enough information about what was happening on the field during VAR reviews.
He said: â€œWe think itâ€™s important in terms of transparency, predominantly to the crowd who at the moment, we donâ€™t think receive enough information.â€
The Premier Leagueâ€™s refereesâ€™ chief, Howard Webb, indicated in May that audio recordings of VAR deliberations could be released next season to help explain contentious decisions.
During a segment on Sky Sports, Webb showed video and audio recordings of interactions between on-field referees and VAR officials discussing in-game situations and decisions.
It was the first time such footage had been shown to Premier League viewers in the UK and, asked by pundit Gary Neville whether more might be released on the day of a game from next season, Webb said increased access was under consideration.
â€œWe are looking to do this as much as we possibly can,â€ he said. â€œWe have made small steps forward. Going forward into next season, we will be looking to do more. FIFA does not allow us to play this out during the game. Who knows where that might go in the future?â€

Anything else to watch out for at the Womenâ€™s World Cup?
Like at the 2022 menâ€™s World Cup in Qatar, semi-automated offsides will be used to help assistant referees that have missed real-time offsides.
The limb-tracking technology, which FIFA says collects 29 data points per player 50 times every second, is intended to make offside decisions more efficient, avoiding frustrating delays for supporters.
Goal-line technology, implemented a decade ago to far more positive reaction than VAR, will also be in use during the Womenâ€™s World Cup.
Collina said that match officials in Australia and New Zealand would be encouraged to be strict in adding additional minutes for stoppages, in a bid to deter time-wasting.
Eleven additional minutes were played at Eden Park on Thursday.
